turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What happened next?

turns.speaker: MISS SELLERS
turns.text: While I was seeing Dr. Paley I mentioned to him one night that someone was stealing drugs from the third floor dispensary.   Three days after I spoke to him in his office he went to the Head Nurse and told her he had witnessed me stealing drugs.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MISS SELLERS
turns.text: There was an inquiry.  It was his word against mine.  They believed him.  I was fired.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I worked for Mr. Marsh for six years. He was a good man -- until she came along.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What changed?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: He did.  Look, I know you can lead a horse to water but you can't make him drink -- but you hold a pail of water in front of an old horse for long enough  -- and well...

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You don't really believe what the district attorney is saying about Miss Lawson, do you?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I don't know.  It's incredible to think that anyone could be capable of doing that -- but if anyone could it would be Rebecca.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I take it you don't like Miss Lawson very much?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I really don't know her that well. We would say hello to each other when I would come to the house, but that was about it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: If you don't know her that well what makes you think she's capable of murder?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Andrew was a kind and gentle man, but he was thirty years older than her. Where's the attraction to sleep with someone like that -- to have the kind of sex they had.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: How do you know what kind of sex they had?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I wasn't lookin' through the keyhole if that's what you're thinking.  I'd come to house sometimes to pick up papers or speak to Andrew.  I'd find their little toys all over the place.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Did Mr. Marsh use drugs?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What about Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes -- cocaine.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: How do you know that?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I was at the house one morning -- I thought Miss Lawson was upstairs with Mr. Marsh.  When I went into the guest bathroom she was standing in front of the mirror pouring this white powder out of a vial.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: How do you know it was cocaine that Miss Lawson had in the bathroom?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: What other kind of white powder do people keep in a vial?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Do you remember the date when you saw Miss Lawson in the bathroom?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes--  It was on a Friday.  I remember because I was going to visit my sister for her birthday.  It would be October twenty-eighth.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Could you repeat the last part of what Mr. Marsh said to you the day before his death?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: He said that if it kept up she was going to kill him.  That his heart couldn't take it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Didn't Mr. Marsh also tell you that Miss Lawson felt bored here and was thinking about going back to Chicago for awhile?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes -- he mentioned it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: So, the woman he loved passionately was thinking about leaving.  That must cause tremendous anxiety. Sleepless nights.  Incredible stress.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I suppose.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: So, isn't it possible that he was confiding in you about the pain he was feeling about losing what might be his last chance for love?  That what he really was saying was that the uncertainty of her leaving was driving him crazy and if it didn't stop it was going to kill him.  That if she did leave his heart couldn't take it.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I don't know.  I'm not sure.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Well, think about it.  Isn't it possible?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.  I suppose it's possible.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Who told you that?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: He video taped you.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: That bastard!

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I thought he was a kind, gentle man?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes, I slept with him but that was a long time ago.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You're lying.  Marsh was wearing a cast on the tape.  It was right before he went to Chicago and met Miss Lawson.  He dumped you for her, didn't he?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: It must have been horrible.  Having to go there -- seeing them together - - knowing he was sleeping with her in the same bed he did with you.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I was jealous.  Of course I was hurt. He switched me off like a little toy he was finished playing with.  But I didn't kill him.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I'm a practical woman Mr. Dulaney. Killing Andrew wasn't in my best interest.  As it is I'm out of a job and I'm not in his will.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Money isn't the only reason people commit murder, Miss Braslow.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I've tried it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You've tried it?  Isn't it true that you've been in and out of Rehab centers for the last four years?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I've been to a few -- yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You don't like Miss Lawson much do you?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You don't like her because you were involved with Mr. Marsh before she came along.  Isn't that true?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You resented the fact that she told you what to do in Mr. Marsh's house?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: And you resented that he cared for her in a way he once cared for you?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: --And that Mr. Marsh paid less attention to you?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: --and that he changed his will?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: In his previous will Mr. Marsh left you two hundred and fifty thousand dollars -- then he cut you out.  Why do you think he did that?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: She talked him into it.  She wanted everything.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Two hundred and fifty thousand dollars is a lot of money.  That must have made you pretty angry?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Well - I'm a little confused.  This is a charge receipt from Rosen's Drug Store where Mr. Marsh had an account.  It's dated the day of the murder.  Is this your signature?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: There's an item you picked up that's marked.  Will you read it?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Dristan nasal spray.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Would you read for us the time of the purchase?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Three fifteen.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: A.M -- or P.M.?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: P.M.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You see that's what bothers me.  No other bottle of nasal spray was found in the house.  The police looked. There was only the one bottle.  But you say you didn't arrive until after Mr. Marsh was dead -- yet we know he was using the nasal spray prior to his death.  How do you think it got there?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Isn't it true that you stopped by the house after you left the drug store and dropped off the items you bought?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Isn't it true that you put the cocaine in the bottle?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: No!  Why would I want to kill him?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Because you were jealous.  Because he cut you out of the will.  Because you have a cocaine habit to feed -- because you know that if Rebecca Lawson is found guilty the new will is void -- and there's a very good chance the old one would be honored.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: You take what people say and make it ugly.  You make others believe what you want them to.  She should have been found guilty.  She shouldn't have gotten off.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Then you would have gotten your money?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You killed him -- didn't you, Joanne?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What do you have in your purse?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: What do you think I've got?  A gun? Maybe I'm gonna kill you too.  Maybe I'll blow your head off right now.

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: I'm gonna go to jail.  I know they're gonna make it look like I did it. They gotta put it on someone.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Why'd you come here?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: To show you this.  It's a letter from that lawyer, Koehler.  He wrote it to me the day after I saw him.  He's the one who told me I could get the money if Miss Lawson went to jail.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You didn't know about it before that?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Then why did you go see Mr. Koehler in the first place?

turns.speaker: JOANNE
turns.text: Because he called me.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Hi, Joe.

turns.speaker: KOEHLER
turns.text: Frank -- what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I need to ask you a question.  What made you get in touch with Joanne Braslow?

turns.speaker: KOEHLER
turns.text: You know I can't talk about that.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'm not asking for names or specifics.  I just want to know what prompted you to make the call?

turns.speaker: KOEHLER
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: And your sexual tastes were something that you hid from Miss Lawson?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: And didn't Miss Lawson come home one day and find you in bed with your male lover?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: And she left shortly after that?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Would it be fair to say that when she did find out it was a shock to her?

turns.speaker: ROSTON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: No further questions.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Are you going to represent me?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: There are no charges against you. I'm here to decide if I'm going to represent you should that occur.  Did you kill him?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Do you think I did it?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I don't know.  That's why I'm asking you.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: You must have some feeling.  Some immediate impression.  A young, attractive woman, involved with an older man who leaves her everything in his will.  And the things that went on in that house.  Such wild sex.  What kind of picture does that paint?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Not a very good one I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: And that's exactly what the jury will see when they look at me.  That's why I need a very good lawyer, Mr. Dulaney.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You're assuming the District Attorney is going to file charges.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: He'll file.  He's an ambitious man. Ambitious men build their careers on the bodies of others.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You still haven't answered my question.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Frank!

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'll have you out in a few hours.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I want you to know right now that the trial's going to be nasty.  Your sex life is going to be dragged through the mud.  They're going to say that you enticed Marsh -- led him down a dark path.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Andrew hardly needed leading.  He was a very passionate man.  He was eager to explore.  I gave him what he wanted.  We fulfilled each others needs.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: This is a very small town -- people here have very straight views on sex.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I'm used to being on the outside looking in.  The same men who will publicly profess their moral outrage for my sexual tastes are the same ones who privately rest their sweaty little hands on my legs and talk about weekend trips together.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Those same men will be sitting on the jury.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I am who I am.  I can't deny it, anymore than you can deny who you are.  I like sex different -- I like it wild.  That's not a crime.  I loved Andrew.  We made love together.  We made it differently, but we still made love.  It was our way.  It was private -- and now the whole world wants to look in through the pretense of justice.  If I was some middle-aged divorcee who screwed him once a week do you think this would be happening to me?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Have you ever seen animals make love, Mr. Dulaney?  They have such passion -- such savage emotion.  They struggle, and snarl, and claw, but neither hurts the other.  Not really.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: No pain, no gain?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Something like that.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: We're not animals.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I think we're getting a little off the subject here.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I thought the subject was sex?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: As it pertains to you -- not me.  Did you always know you had different... tastes?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I don't know if it's something I can explain to you.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Because -- it's beyond intellect. It's emotion.  It's passion.  It has to be experienced -- it can't be imagined.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Try.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: When I was growing up we had a strawberry patch in our backyard. So did this family down the road.  I used to sneak in their yard and steal their strawberries.  It wasn't easy. The stone walls were high and I'd scrape my knees as I climbed over. On the other side were wild rose bushes.  The thorns would dig into my legs and cut my thighs as I lowered myself down.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: If you had what you wanted at home why did you sneak into their yard?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Because -- somehow the fruit always tasted that much sweeter because of the pain it took to get to it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: How'd you meet Marsh?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I was at a cocktail party.  Very trendy.  Andrew was in Chicago on business.  He had broken his wrist the week before and was wearing it in a sling.  He looked so helpless.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: -- And then?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: We started talking.  In fact, we talked until four in the morning.  We discovered we shared a lot of the same interests.  After that we were together all the time until he left. He used to call me every night after he came back.  Then after a few weeks he invited me to come visit him. I've never left.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Why didn't you live together?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Can we get out of here?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Sure.  Where to?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: This is your house.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Because, I'm your attorney.  I shouldn't be going to your house.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Is it against the law?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: No -- it just doesn't look right.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I think the photographer's probably a voyeur.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I'm the photographer.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Oh -- Well, they're different.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: That's not an answer.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: It's not my taste.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Tastes can change.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Not true.  Shall I tell you what you were thinking?  You were wondering if I was wearing anything under my skirt.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Hi.  It's Frank.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Hi, Frank.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I just wanted to see if my secretary called to confirm your appointment tomorrow.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Yes -- she did.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Great.  I'll see you at the office at nine.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: No -- not at the office.  I've got a better idea.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Andrew loved this old cabin.  He always dreamed about moving to Tahiti -- living in a hut and becoming a beach-bum.  I could never imagine myself doing that -- but somehow when he talked about it, he made it sound so alive - - so wonderful.  Soft ocean breezes and beautiful sunsets -- leaving the world and it's problems behind.  I wish he'd had a chance to do it.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: It's okay.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Tell me about Doctor Paley?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I hardly know him.  He wanted me and he couldn't have me.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: It's going to be hard to convince a jury that he's testifying against you in a murder trial because you blew him off.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: It won't be that hard.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Did you always want to be a lawyer?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: No -- I wanted to be a professional hockey player.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: That seems so far away from who you are now.  What happened?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I broke my ankle skating.  That ended that dream.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: It's hard to let go of a dream, isn't it?  To let go of what you want?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Yes -- it would be nice.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What would?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: You and me -- making love.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Is that what you think I was thinking?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: No -- that's what I know you were thinking.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: There's nothing wrong in admitting that you want me, Frank.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You take a lot for granted.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You lied to me!

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I just left Joanne Braslow.  She told me she saw you doing cocaine at Marsh's house!

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: She's mistaken.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: That's not good enough, Goddamit!

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: It isn't true.  You have to believe me.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: No, I don't have to believe you.  The jury has to believe you and answers like he's lying or she's mistaken aren't going to convince them.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I don't use cocaine anymore.  If she says she saw me doing it she's lying.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Why would she lie?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I don't know, Frank -- but don't you think that's something we should find out?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I called you all weekend.  Where were you?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I went out on the boat.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Alone?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: You were brilliant today.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: It's only the beginning.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Can I see you later?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: You can see me now.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Something wrong?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Paley could be a problem tomorrow.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I'm sure you'll be able to handle him.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'm glad you have such confidence in me.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Don't worry about Paley.  He can't touch me.  No one can.  I've thought it all out.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What does that mean?  You've been thinking about the case?  Or you thought everything out before you killed Marsh?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Sugar or honey?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Honey.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Rebecca -- take these off.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Tonight we open new doors.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What are you going you doing?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Are you scared?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What's that for?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: To celebrate how masterfully you destroyed Roston today.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Rebecca -- we shattered a man's life in open court.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Fuck him!  He tried to shatter mine.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: He was only doing what he thought was right.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: You're too weak, Frank.  When you want something you have to do what- ever it takes to get it.  If something gets in your way you remove it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You killed him -- didn't you?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I knew you were thinking that.  I could see it in your eyes today in the courtroom.  You're wrong, Frank. I need you to believe that.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You don't need anybody.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I do need you.  No matter what you think of me -- I didn't do it.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'm dropping the case.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: No -- you're not.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: You can think whatever you want, Frank -- but I didn't kill Andrew, and I'm not going to prison for something I didn't do.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You're a monster.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: No -- I'm a survivor.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Frank -- It's Rebecca.  I need to see you right away.  I've got the tape.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You killed him.  You killed him -- and I got you off.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: That's crazy.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I've been thinking about that.  I've decided to give it to you after I've collected the inheritance.  You can take that one if you want -- but there's another copy.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: That wasn't the deal.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: So, sue me.  Things have changed.  I think you should go home -- and after you leave I see no reason for us to ever have contact again.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'm not leaving without that tape.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Don't push me, Frank.  I might lose my temper and send it out just for spite.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: She's right, Paley.  You've got to kill me.  She doesn't have to -- she's free -- she can't be tried again -- but you, you planned it with her.  You supplied the Coke.  You're an accessory to murder.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Shoot him.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: No -- he's lying.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: How's it supposed to work Rebecca? You and Paley celebrate your victory. You get me over here and provoke a fight so he has to rush in and save you -- but then he's given himself away as your accomplice -- now he has to kill me.  After that I figure she'll tell the Police that you broke in.  That you were crazed because we humiliated you in court?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Don't listen to him.  Can't you see he's trying to turn you against me.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Andrew Marsh was a very wealthy man. A trial like this is going to put Cardenas in the spot-light.

turns.speaker: SATTLER
turns.text: We've already got press arriving from over the country and she hasn't even been charged yet. Cardenas wants to see her in his office tomorrow at ten.  I'd like you to go with her.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'm supposed to be on vacation.

turns.speaker: SATTLER
turns.text: I know -- but she wants you to represent her if Cardenas files.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SATTLER
turns.text: Because I told her you were the best criminal attorney we have.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Raymond, I'm the only criminal attorney you have.

turns.speaker: SATTLER
turns.text: Well, I guess that makes you the best.  Look, Frank -- she stands to inherit three million dollars.  As executors of the estate and her attorneys that could generate a lot of legal fees for us.  All I'm asking you to do is talk to her.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Alright, I'll talk to her

turns.speaker: SATTLER
turns.text: She's waiting in the conference room.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What are they saying?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: The kids at school say she humped Mr. Marsh to death.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Hey, you know better than that.  What did I teach you to say when someone is accused of doing something?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: She allegedly humped him to death?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You know how it is sometimes when you're out playing ball with your friends?  How you're really concentrating on what you're doing -- and you lose track of time and you come home late and Mom yells at you?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Well, that's kind of how I am right now.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Is Mom yelling at you too?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I love you too, Dad.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Michael -- get off the phone.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Because I'm expecting a call.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: -- But it's Sunday.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I know what day it is!  Get off the phone.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I gotta go.  I'll call you later.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: Do it quickly, Mr. Dulaney.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: "Discourteous insinuations about his sexual abilities."  Who told you to say that?

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: Mr. Dulaney, before you cast aspersions on the District Attorney's Office by suggesting they've coaxed this witness to say things that aren't true -- you better have more than a hunch.  Do you?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: No, Your Honor.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: Maybe you don't know what it's like where Mrs. Crawford comes from -- but I do.  I came from a neighborhood just like hers.  This is a whole other world for her.  She's a poor working woman who has been thrust into a room full of highly educated and mostly unsympathetic people.  So, she puts on her best dress, fixes her hair and tries to present herself as intelligently as possible.  Being poor and having pride is not a crime, Mr. Dulaney -- and before you attempt to impeach another witness' testimony in my courtroom -- your foundations better be based on something other than semantics.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: But Your Honor--

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: That's it, Mr. Dulaney.  Take a seat.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Objection.  The witness has already stated that Miss Lawson left without an explanation.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: Mr. Cardenas, I suggest you move on to another line of questioning.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: The witness will answer the question.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Mr. Roston?

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: Miss Braslow, I'd like to remind you that you are still under oath.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: How often do you use cocaine?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Your Honor -- the prosecution has introduced cocaine as one of the contributing reasons Mr. Marsh died. How it may have been introduced into the household is of vital importance.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: Are you able to back up this allegation -- or are you fishing?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I can back it up.

turns.speaker: JUDGE BURNHAM
turns.text: You better.  Please answer the question.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: You're on vacation, remember?  You're supposed to be relaxing.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I am relaxing.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: This is not relaxing.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: And I suppose you're going to show me how to relax?

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: If you want me to.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'm always open to learning new things.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Can't it wait?

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: No -- it has to be done by tomorrow.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Hello?... Hi Raymond.... What?... Well, I was sort of planning on... Alright... Okay, goodbye.  That was Sattler.  He thinks the D.A.'s going to file on Rebecca Lawson.  He wants me in the office tomorrow morning.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: We're supposed to go to the lake.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I know.  What can I do?  He is the boss.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: He could let you have your vacation.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: I swear -- the both of you.  Some example you set.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Some example you set.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: How can Cardenas possibly think he can build a case against two consenting adults?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: He must have something or he wouldn't be pressing so hard.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: If he files are you going to take the case?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I don't know yet.  I want to hear what she says at her statement tomorrow.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: What's she like?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Attractive.  Bright.  Distant. Charming when she wants to be.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: She sounds like quite a woman.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Yeah -- but can she cook?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Humped

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I can think of worse ways to go--

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Frank -- I know you're busy, but Michael asked me after dinner if you were angry with him.  He wanted to know why you weren't talking to him.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'll talk to him later.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Why don't you talk to him now?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Because I go to trial in seven weeks. I've got a lot of preparing to do.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: No one's asking you not to work.  I just think you could make some time for your son.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Is that alright, Frank?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Yeah -- fine.  Excuse me.  I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Yeah -- what are you doing up?

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: We have to talk.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: That's what I was hoping you'd tell me.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Sharon, it's late.  Can we get to the point?

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Where have you been?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Working.  Charlie and I were going over some statements.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Charlie called at eleven thirty looking for you.  You were with her, weren't you?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Why did you lie to me?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Because I knew you'd think exactly what you're thinking.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: This isn't a courtroom.  Don't try to turn this around on me.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I'm not.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: You're sleeping with her, aren't you?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: It's bad enough that you are.  It's even worse that you can stand here and lie to me.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I was thinking that when the trial is over we'd all go skiing for a weekend.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Maybe it would be a good idea if you just took Michael.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Talk to me.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You wouldn't like what you'd see. You don't know me anymore.  I don't know me anymore.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: We can't pretend this isn't happening.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Please -- not now.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Why didn't you come to me?

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: You used to like to touch me -- to make love to me.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: It's more involved than that.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: It was a place to start.

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: You think that's the answer?  Sex? Is that what you want?  You want me to make love to you?

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: I don't want our lives ruined because of this.  I love you, Frank.  I want this to work -- but you have to help me.  You have to come back from where ever it is you are.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Frank -- stop it!  Stop it!

turns.speaker: DULANEY
turns.text: Is this what you want -- huh?  Is it?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Albert's got the stomach flu.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: That's too bad.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No, it's not.  Now I get to pitch.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Michael, you shouldn't be happy when someone else isn't feeling well.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Not even if they're a dork?

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: Not even if they're a dork.  You should go by and see how he's feeling.
